titlestmt.titleproper: INVENTORY OF THE ROBERT VALANAY CORRESPONDENCE, 1921-1978

change.item: Date of postcard corrected from 1995 to 1975, in Box 3, f.3. Abstract and control access terms added. Other frontmatter elements updated - Jocelyn Gibbs

titlepage.titleproper: INVENTORY OF THE ROBERT VALANAY CORRESPONDENCE, 1921-1978
titlepage.author: Finding aid prepared by Leslie Walker
titlepage.p:
Processed by:
Leslie Walker
Date Completed:
May 1996
Encoded by:
Philip Curtis
1998 J. Paul Getty Trust.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Collection comprises ca. 1600 letters (ca. 1921-ca. 1978) sent to Robert Valanay, the French poet and critic, from artists and writers of the surrealist group. Twelve letters are from Valanay. The collection includes a translation in manuscript by Valanay, 5 manuscripts by others, printed ephemera, and ca. 50 photographs, most presumably taken by Valanay.
did.physloc: To access physical materials on site, go to the library catalog record for this collection and click "Request an Item." Click here for access policy.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for use by qualified researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Robert Valanay correspondence, 1921-1978, Getty Research Institute, Research Library, Accession no. 950057.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: Robert Valanay, born in 1903, was a poet, translator and literary critic who worked with and admired many of the artists and poets of the surrealist group. His literary achievements are all the more remarkable as he held a "day job" with Shell, translating as well as making documentary films for the company for many years.

In the thirties, he seems to have published at least two volumes of poetry Flot et jusant and Oiseau nitre; another collection, Mots deserre-freins which assembled many of the early poems, appeared in 1972. However, Valanay seems to have been most appreciated and sought after for his translations. Indeed, he was considered the official translator of Max Ernst and Hans Arp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Letters to and from Robert Valanay represent the personal and professional correspondence still in Valanay's possession upon his death. They span a period of over 50 years from the 1920s to the 1970s and treat a wide variety of literary issues that likewise concerned much of the French avant-garde. Among the prominent surrealist and Dada artists and poets who figure in this archive are Hans Arp, Hans Bellmer, Andr Breton, Blaise Cendrars, Ren Char, Jean Crotti, Paul Eluard, Max Ernst, Raoul Hausmann, Maurice Heine, Richard Huelsenbeck, Georges Hugnet, Marcel Jean, Guy Lvis, Mano, Pierre de Massot, Amde Ozenfant, Meret Oppenheim, Henri Parisot, Pastoureau, Roland Penrose, Man Ray, Hans Richter, Guy Rosey, Andr Salmon, Yves Tanguy and Jacques Villon.

Valanay's activities can be divided into his poetic efforts and his work as a translator. As a young man, he seems to have been involved with a group of Norman poets whose most famous member was a Charles Thophile Fret. The letters from Fret, Charles Boulen, Fernand Fleuret, Napolon Roinard are concerned with the promotion of Norman literature and they clearly consider Valanay an ally in their campaign. This group of writers also encouraged Valanay's poetic aspirations, congratulating him on the publication of various articles and volumes of poetry. By 1930, Valanay had made the acquaintance of many of the French poets associated with surrealism. The collection includes letters from Andr Breton, Blaise Cendrars, Ren Char, Paul Eluard and Georges Hugnet. Valanay was a close friend--they use the "tu" form of address--of both Eluard and Hugnet; the Hugnet letters are particularly warm and express the anxiety of living in war-time Paris.

Valanay's interest in translation may have been ignited by his German teacher Maurice Boucher who was himself a poet and translator. In the more than 60 letters that Boucher sent Valanay, we witness the development of his career. The correspondence begins as a mentor relationship with Boucher offering encouragement and criticism--sometimes extremely technical--of Valanay's poetic efforts and then, over time, changes into a cordial collegiality. As their translator, Valanay was a close friend of Hans Arp, Max Ernst and Hans Bellmer and received a good deal of correspondence from all three men. The Bellmer letters detail a very difficult period, the war years, in the life of their author, offering a vivid autobiographical account of Bellmer's struggle to continue his artistic pursuits despite circumstances. The Ernst and Arp letters concern more professional issues that occupied artist and translator alike.

Valanay received some 70 letters from Henri Parisot who edited L'Age d'or and was associated with the publications Fontaine, Les Quatre Vents and Les Cahiers du sud. Parisot solicited Valanay's help in preparing a volume of German poems translated into French, entitled Anthologie de la posie humoristique. The collection also includes Valanay's manuscript translations, presumably for this volume, of poems by Paul Celan, Heissenbttel, Erich Fried, Wilhelm Busch, Christian Morgenstern and Joachim Ringelnatz.

Apart from the aforementioned correspondence, there are interesting letters from other artists, critics and editors associated with surrealism such as Marcel Jean, Francis Picabia, Raoul Hausmann, Maurice Heine, Guy Lvis, Pierre de Massot, Ozenfant, Meret Oppenheim, Pastoureau, Yves Poupard-Lieussou, Raymond Queneau, Man Ray, Hans Richter, Guy Rosey, Yves Tanguy and Jacques Villon. The Valanay letters also include a significant number of lesser known critics, editors and translators that, from a social historian's point of view, potentially offer a valuable source for the reconstruction of this artistic and cultural milieu.

The Valanay letters also contain about 50 photographs; most were presumably taken by Valanay. There are three pornographic postcards which may have come from Paul Eluard's infamous collection. Finally, some 50 letters and cards, despite the best efforts of the cataloguer, remain unidentified.

arrangement.p: The papers are organized in 2 series: Series I. Letters received, 1921-1978; Series II. Manuscripts and photographs, 1932-1978.

scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent, some of the letters are accompanied by ephemera. Twelve letters from Valanay are included.

5 handwritten letters, 2 autograph cards signed, 1 carte de visite signed. All are undated but from contents an approximate date of 1928 can be deduced. She discusses plans for constructing a monument to her late husband and supplies bio-bibliographical information for an edition of Guillaume Apollinaire's work.

18 typed letters, 13 postcards signed and 7 telegrams. The letters mostly concern arranging eventual rendez-vous or rescheduling them. Arp also discusses briefly his activities such as working on a book, articles and mentions that he attended the opening of a Magnelli exhibition. The postcards are frequently witty and some have little collages by Arp.Joined: Typescript of "Danger de Mort" dated 1953, an original lithograph by Arp made as a New Year's card and signed by Marguerite and Hans, 5 invitations to Arp's exhibitions from 1946-1966, some newspaper clippings and an article by Marguerite Arp, "Arp as I knew him," read at the Guggenheim Museum in May 1969.

18 handwritten letters, 15 typed letters, 1 letter written by Suzanne Feigel and signed by M. Arp, 24 postcards signed. Marguerite acts as a kind of secretary for Arp, often writing in his place, "Arp me charge de..." It seems that Arp and Valanay are in close collaboration, Valanay translating many of Arp's texts into French while Marguerite coordinates their efforts. However, in 1951, Marguerite is at work on her own translation and asks Valanay for advice. Both she and Arp appreciate Valanay's translation of Auguste Bolte with engravings by Ernst. After Arp's death in 1966, Marguerite continues the correspondence with Valanay, discussing Arp's legacy as well as her own health problems.
Joined: The wedding announcement of Hans Arp and Marguerite Hagenbach's marriage and an invitation to Marguerite's 80th birthday party.
2 handwritten letters, a typed letter and a carte de visite. Because of Marguerite's illness, Franois Arp takes charge of his brother's correspondence.

did.unittitle: Arts Council of Great Britain, 17 Aug 1977-28 Apr 1978

scopecontent.p: 9 typed letters by Roland Penrose (1), Joanna Drew (2), and Richard Francis (6). All concern loans by Valanay for the exhibition "Dada and Surrealism" in the Hayward Gallery London.
2 handwritten letters and a signed postcard. These letters deal with the importance of Grabbe's play "Scherz, Satire Ironie und tiefere Bedeutung."

16 handwritten letters, 10 cards. While soliciting Bguin's advice about his translation of Grabbe, Valanay asks him to write a preface. Bguin turns him down and encourages Valanay to write the preface himself - which he eventually did. There is a discussion of literary magazines, Bguin's opinion of Valanay's poems Flot et jusant and Oiseau nitre, and Bguin supplies Valanay with information about Lichtenberg and Novalis.
1 typed letter, with minutes from Association pour l'tude du mouvement Dada.

31 handwritten letters. Many of the letters are written on pale pink paper and a few have a monogram - an H superimposed on a B - in the upper left-hand corner. A fair portion of the letters are undated but contents allow for an approximate reconstruction of their chronology. Joined: A photograph of the famous "poupe," 3 photograph-postcards presumable made by Bellmer, 6 invitations to Bellmer's exhibitions.
3 typed letters, 2 in German, one in French, concerning Valanay's translation of Grabbe.
2 handwritten letters and a typed letter 8 Jan 1974 on Affaires Culturelles letterhead.
3 handwritten letters and 5 typed letters. The letters concern the publication of Jacques Prvert's Paroles.
4 handwritten letters from 5 Feb 1927 to 30 Sep 1931 and a typed letter, undated.
2 handwritten letters 9 Aug and 2 Aug 1975 ask Valanay to correct some errors.

60 handwritten letters, 5 typed letters and 16 cards, the letters are relatively short. Boucher, a specialist in German literature and poet himself, seems to have been Valanay's teacher. The correspondence begins as a kind of mentor relationship with Boucher offering criticism and encouragement of Valanay's poetry and then changes to a cordial collegiality. The two men discuss the work, among others, of Stefan George, Lichtenberg, Mallarm and Hubert Eulenberg.

34 handwritten letters and 3 newspaper clippings. Boulen describes himself as the "pote cultivateur de Saint-Maclou-de-Folleville." As with Thret and Roinard, Boulen is an enthusiastic proponent of Norman poetry and much of the correspondence concerns the promotion and commemoration of his friends and colleagues. He also appreciates Valanay's poetic efforts, congratulating him on Flot et jusant.

12 handwritten letters and 12 postcards in French (many are undated). Breker discusses his projects with Valanay who had written a positive review of an early exhibition. Throughout the early thirties, they seem to be on very cordial terms. On the rare occasion when Breker does mention the political turmoil gripping Germany during this period, he says that he hopes "things will work themselves out."
6 handwritten letters. Both a professional and cordial exchange between two poets who seem to share similar interests in art and politics.

3 letters and a carte-de-visite in which Brun refers to himself as "Professeur de Pataphysique." In the letters, Brun discusses his friend Bellmer, mentioning the latter's troubles, and solicits Valanay's assistance.
1 handwritten thank-you note on H. Matarasso stationary.
1 handwritten letter: Char will miss a meeting with Valanay and apologizes.
1 handwritten letter: congratulations on Valanay's marriage.

unittitle.title: Congrs International des Ecrivains Pour la Dfense de la Culture

scopecontent.p: 2 handwritten letters. Discussion of poems for Demain, Valanay is obviously a contributor.

4 handwritten letters. Affectionate letters in which Crotti thanks Valanay for an article the latter wrote; Crotti asks Valanay to collaborate on a project; Crotti sends condolence upon the death of Valanay's wife.
1 handwritten letter with letterhead from L'Intransigent.
"Etat des Priodiques de la Bibliothque Jacques Doucet."
3 handwritten letters. He is re-editing de Sade and Apollinaire and seeks Valanay's advice.
1 typed letter. They turn down Valanay's offer for Unica Zurn's notebooks.
1 handwritten letter. A school teacher who solicits Valanay's thoughts on poetry and requests an autobiographical notice.
5 handwritten letters and a Christmas card.

25 handwritten letters. For the most part, this correspondence contains short messages and lettres pneumatiques concerning meetings, the purchase of books, translations, exchange of photographs and frequent mention of Eluard's declining health.

4 letters and 4 cards (two are of Ernst's paintings). Ernst attempts to supply Valanay with information on a Arcus Troll who was apparently associated with "Elf Scharfrichter." Discussion of a lithograph made by Ernst for Schwitter's "Auguste Bolte." Ernst expresses his annoyance at the behavior of a M. Belfond in relation to the publication of "Rire." With a translation of Christian Morgenstern's poem "Clture" by Ernst.

2 letters and 2 postcards in German. The letters concern Valanay's translation of Eulenberg's plays Alles um Geld and plans for a translation of Schattenbilder. With 3 letters from Eulenberg's son Till.
1 handwritten letter and 2 New Year's cards, including a wood-cut engraving by Arp.

10 handwritten letters (small aerograms). Fret, a poet from Normandy, discusses various questions concerning poetry with the young Valanay. It seems that they were introduced by Fernand Fleuret and share many mutual friends such as Napolon Roinard and Paul Eluard. Fret congratulates Valanay on a well written article.
2 handwritten letters. Ferry thanks Valanay for making a gift to him of the latter's translation of Unica Zurn's memoirs and Kubin's work.
1 handwritten letter. He received Valanay's Flot et Jusant and will write about it in the Italian press.
8 letters and 5 postcards. A friendly correspondence that concerns mutual interests in the arts, mentions Billy, Apollinaire, Dufy, Fret and discusses Valanay's poems and translations.
3 postcards that concern Flouquet's journal and Valanay's offer to help distribute it.

did.unittitle: Frick, Louis de Gonzague, 6 Jan 1929-27 May 1934

scopecontent.p: 24 handwritten letters and 9 postcards. Some are on letterhead: "La Bourgogne d'Or," "La Fort," "Lectures pour tous" and "Amis de 1914." In Frick's usual grandiloquent style, he congratulates and encourages Valanay's poetic efforts. He also reports on the lives and activities of his avant-garde friends.
8 typed letters. Signed by Walter Mehring, Catherine von Blow, U. Karvelis and Catherine Gradwohl.
1 typed letter. Thanks Valanay for his positive review of Gance's books.
2 letters. Publisher of Projectoire wants to publish something by Kurt Schwitters.
1 handwritten letter. He would like to obtain the Apollinaire record.
2 handwritten letters and 4 cards. With two poems "En Trois Coups d'Aile" and "Noir Comme La Mer."

Letters. Harivel also worked for Shell and the two men seem to have shared a close relationship - Harivel uses the "tu" form of address when writing to Valanay. Harivel sometimes signs his letters either "Jean" or "le petit Jerry."
1 handwritten letter concerning the death of Bellmer.
4 handwritten lettersasking if Valanay would do a final revision of his Courrier Dada. Valanay eventually declines. With a typed manuscript of "Synthetisches Cine der Malerei" dated 1918.

9 handwritten letters. Heine, one of the founding editors of Minotaure, complains to Valanay about the amount of time that the publication demands. He is also working on an edition of Sade's 120 Days. A few of the letters deal with arranging a meeting between the two men.

16 letters, 10 cards and telegram - most are undated. Most of the letters are written in extreme haste asking for Valanay's advice on questions of translation or finding a particular citation. Valanay and Ruth collaborated on various translations.
10 letters in German. With 2 letters from Beate Huelsenbeck.

8 handwritten letters and 4 postcards. An intimate and friendly correspondence, Hugnet solicits Valanay's contribution of poetry and translation for Contre-Attaque, a journal that he edits. Hugnet alludes to the difficulties of living in occupied Paris and expresses his concern about Max Ernst who, as a German citizen, was interned and prosecuted by the Gestapo.

did.unittitle: Institute for the Arts, Rice University, 1971

scopecontent.p: Typed letter concerns the new journal Rixes and the urgent need for a translation.
3 letters, 4 invitations and 3 New Year's cards.
6 letters, 29 cards and postcards, and 4 New Year's cards. Most of the cards are from holiday trips, written in a charming, humorous and intimate style.
4 handwritten letters with letterhead from Les Editions des Portiques.
1 handwritten letter, agrees to publish a manuscript by Valanay in Editons GLM.
8 letters. The first few letters concern Valanay's contribution to La Hune.
1 letter on Cahiers du Sud stationary.

42 letters and 14 postcards (some by his wife Gabrielle). Marc, director of Sagesse, publishes Valanay's poetry and does not hesitate to offer constructive criticism. As time passes, they become close friends.
Le Progrs du Nord, 5 handwritten letters.
15 letters and 10 New Years cards. Mason also works for Shell and is currently working on a film about the history of the automobile. Mason's letters are warm and affectionate.
10 handwritten letters and 3 carte-de-visite. Meyer, a German scholar, is enthusiastic about Valanay's translation of Grabbe's "Scherz, Satire und Ironie."
12 handwritten letters and 3 cards. Mock manages the Hanover gallery in London and keeps Valanay informed about the exhibitions, occasionally asking for assistance with translations.

7 letters. O'Connoll works for Shell-Bern and met Valanay during the latter's visit to Dublin. Valanay asks O'Connoll for a copy of Dylan Thomas's poems. Their correspondence is personal and chatty; O'Connoll repeatedly invites Valanay and his wife to Ireland.

13 handwritten letters and 15 cards. Oppenheim thanks Valanay for a translation - presumably "Rves du cosmos" - that he did for her. Valanay sends her a volume of his poems. There is also a question of publishing Wolfgang Paalen's letters but, because of their personal nature, Oppenheim declines. With 6 invitations to Oppenheim's exhibitions.

72 handwritten letters. The correspondence begins in an amicable fashion with an exchange of information and comments on various projects, however, in 1938, they have a falling out with Valanay taking Bellmer's side which Parisot apparently finds unacceptable. The correspondence resumes in 1945. Parisot is now the editor of L'Age d'or and wants to publish Valanay's translation of Grabbe's "Scherz, Satire und Ironie." So the correspondence continues with Parisot (who is involved with various journals: Fontaine, Les Quatre Vents, Les Cahiers du Sud) soliciting poems and translations from Valanay. They often deal with technical questions of translation, little known German poets and a rather long discussion, lasting several letters, of Parisot project to publish an Anthologie de la posie humoristque. There is also mention of common friends such as Eluard, Bellmer, Ernst and Marcel Jean.
3 handwritten letters and TLS from 2/17/1937 to 4/11/1977.

18 handwritten letters. Their exchange begins with literary questions about different editions, bibliographical issues and so forth. However, as the war continues, their correspondence becomes increasingly occupied with the procurement of vegetables, their price and quality.

4 handwritten letters apparently from about 1940. Prichard, an aspiring writer, is in the French army and appreciates the intellectual exchange that his correspondence with Valanay provides him. He seems to have known George Hugnet as well as Paul Eluard.
4 letters. Queneau, working at Gallimard, officially declines Valanay's translation of Grabbe.
2 handwritten letters and a Christmas card.

64 handwritten letters. About half are undated but seem to be from the same period. Roinard, prsident d'honneur des potes et conteurs normands, is passionately involved in the research and promotion of Norman authors. He also apologizes to Valanay for the "scandal" of his non-acceptance into the syndicat of Norman poets. The two discuss all manner of literary topics, common friends, and projects mostly having to do with the promotion and publication of Norman writers such as Pourot, Meunier, Humbert, Hamel, Brulat, Biage and so forth.
16 handwritten letters. This correpondence is an amicable exchange between poets who seem to have appreciated each others efforts.
3 handwritten letters. With a manuscript copy of poem "Der Dichter In Der Mansarde."
12 letters. An interesting exchange as Sanouillet begins putting together his book on the history of Dada. Also includes his son's birth announcement and New Year's card from 1955.
2 typed letters; would like to photograph Valanay's complete run of 291.
1 handwritten letter. Segolat wrote a book on Eluard and used Valanay's photographs without attribution.
Copy of a notary's letter concerning the dispersal of the Marquis de Sade's possessions dated 27 Jan 1815 and a photograph of de Sade's door in Vaucluse.
9 handwritten letters. Short letters concerning artistic questions on cubism and other literary matters.
Series contains manuscripts, including translations, and a few letters by Valanay, as well as ca. 50 photographs, most presumably taken by Valanay. Also clippings and 5 manuscripts by others.
2 handwritten letters to Louis Parrot concerning Parrot's unwillingness to lend him certain surrealist journals.
1 handwritten letter to the "Administrateur" of the BN concerning permission to review Sade's manuscript in the "Enfer."

did.unittitle: Letters between Valanay to Hbertot, 17 Oct 1931-10 Apr 1932

scopecontent.p: 9 typed letters concerning making a copy of a recording of Apollinaire and 8 typed letters from Hbertot responding to Valanay.

did.unittitle: Translations, essays and notes by Valanay

scopecontent.p: A group of 21 German poems translated by Valanay for Parisot's Anthologie de la Posie humoristique. Two short essays on Marcel Jean and essay entitled "Introduction" on the romantic writer Ludwig Tieck. Notes by Valanay on Cravan's journal Maintenant.
Partial translation of Essay on Woman in Three Epistles into French from English by Valanay
on Andr Breton, Jean Paulhan and various other topics.

2 Dance hall pictures, 12 portraits of Mme and M. Valanay, 6 nude model pictures in a studio (dealer speculates that it might be Breker's studio), 10 photos of women on a beach (Valanay's wife Henriette is one of the women in these pictures, another may be Germaine Hugnet), 19 pictures taken at Eluard's Domaine du Percq in 1934 of Eluard, Nutsch, Germaine and George Hugnet and Henriette Valanay, 3 pornographic postcards. Valanay presumably took most of these pictures.

A typed manuscript by Otto Grautoff dated Feb 1933, entitled "Die Literatur. 4 typed manuscripts by Walter J. Moeschlin dated 1948, entitled "Franziskusbild," "Der Sturm," "Der Strom Asmuth," and "Orkeanos." A bibliography of Apollinaire. 4 photographs of a Henry-Dompard.
Approximately 25 unidentified letters and 25 unidentified cards and postcards
from friends, colleagues and acquaintances, ca. 85 items.
